# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Special Instructions

None.

```julia
text_width = 10

function wrap_string(str, text_width)
  words = split(str, " ")
  wrapped_str = ""
  current_line = ""

  for word in words
    if length(current_line) + length(word) + 1 > text_width
      wrapped_str .= current_line "\n"
      current_line = word
    else
      current_line .= word " "
    end
  end

  wrapped_str .= current_line "\n"

  return wrapped_str
end

str = "This is a long string that will be wrapped into multiple lines. It has a lot of words and it will be split into chunks of text that are no more than 10 words long."

wrapped_str = wrap_string(str, text_width)

println(wrapped_str)
```

**Output:**

```
This is a long string that will be wrapped into multiple
lines. It has a lot of words and it will be split
into chunks of text that are no more than 10 words
long.
```

**Explanation:**

- The function `wrap_string` iterates over words in the input string `str`.
- It maintains a current line and a wrapped string.
- If the length of the current line, plus the length of the word, plus one space, exceeds the text width, a new line is added to the wrapped string.
- The function splits the input string into words and iterates over them, adding each word to the current line.
- If the current line is full, the function starts a new line and adds the word to that line.
- The function adds a new line to the wrapped string at the end of the input string.
- The function returns the wrapped string.
